# UISwitch

**Class**

A control that offers a binary choice, such as on/off.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor class UISwitch
```

## Overview

The [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UISwitch] class declares a property and a method to control its on/off state. When a person manipulates the switch control (“flips” it), it triggers the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIControl/Event/valueChanged] event.

You can customize the appearance of the switch by changing the color used to tint the switch when it’s on or off.

For information about basic view behaviors, see [https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/WindowsViews/Conceptual/ViewPG_iPhoneOS/Introduction/Introduction.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40009503].

## Creating a switch

- **init(frame:)**: Creates a switch control.
- **init(coder:)**: Creates a switch control from data in an unarchiver.

## Setting the on/off state

- **isOn**: A Boolean value that determines whether the switch is in the on or off position.
- **setOn(_:animated:)**: Sets the state of the switch to the on or off position, optionally animating the transition.

## Setting the display style

- **Displaying a checkbox in your Mac app built with Mac Catalyst**: Present a switch control as a Mac-style checkbox when your app runs in the Mac user interface idiom.
- **preferredStyle**: The preferred display style for the switch.
- **style**: The display style for the switch.
- **UISwitch.Style**: Styles that determine the appearance of the switch.
- **title**: The title displayed next to a checkbox-style switch.

## Customizing the appearance of the switch

- **onTintColor**: The color used to tint the appearance of the switch when it’s in the on position.
- **thumbTintColor**: The color used to tint the appearance of the thumb.

## Deprecated

- **onImage**: The image displayed when the switch is in the on position.
- **offImage**: The image displayed when the switch is in the off position.

## Controls

- **Responding to control-based events using target-action**: Handle user input by connecting buttons, sliders, and other controls to your app’s code using the target-action design pattern.
- **UIControl**: The base class for controls, which are visual elements that convey a specific action or intention in response to user interactions.
- **UIButton**: A control that executes your custom code in response to user interactions.
- **UIColorWell**: A control that displays a color picker.
- **UIDatePicker**: A control for inputting date and time values.
- **UIPageControl**: A control that displays a horizontal series of dots, each of which corresponds to a page in the app’s document or other data-model entity.
- **UISegmentedControl**: A horizontal control that consists of multiple segments, each segment functioning as a discrete button.
- **UISlider**: A control for selecting a single value from a continuous range of values.
- **UIStepper**: A control for incrementing or decrementing a value.
